Body:
BC-WENDYS-MURDER-ART-2NDTAKE-NYT 
  
 NEW YORK: the attack. 

   On Thursday morning, members of Jaquione Johnson's large family
filed into a hospital waiting room, pacing and awaiting word from
doctors, who were still operating.

   ``Doctors said he can't move his right side at all, but he has
sensation in it,'' his aunt, Regina Johnson, said. ``His teeth are
completely shattered.''

   Finally Joretta Johnson was allowed into the intensive care unit
see her son, nicknamed ``Fluff Love'' because his hair looks so
soft and fluffy when it is unbraided. Ms. Johnson, her eyes puffy
and red and tired, had been through something like this last year
when her older son was shot and seriously wounded. This time, she
turned to her family and said, ``I'm asking for everybody's
prayers.''

   At the restaurant, a co-worker, Olga Purdie, whose 2-9 shift
overlapped with the victims', rattled off their names and burst
into tears. ``Jean, Ramon, Ali, Jeremy, Anita, Jaquione,'' she
sobbed. ``They were my co-workers. They were my friends.''

   And Thursday night, two detectives were sent to Castro's home in
Queens to protect their leading witness in the case. ``We fear for
his life,'' one friend said.

   Brown, the district attorney, spent three hours at the scene and
promised ``a full court press'' to arrest the culprits. It was the
worst massacre in Queens since 1995, when six people were murdered
in a College Point condominium.

   But in the Flushing area, considered by many to be the cultural
heart of the borough, the residents, almost to a person, say they
feel safer there than when they travel to any other part of New
York.

   Beyond the shadow of Manhattan's skyscrapers, Flushing in the
last 20 years has become one of the city's most dynamic business
districts, with scores of stores and foreign banks and crowded
sidewalks, having supplanted Chinatown in Manhattan as the city's
Asian hub.

   It is considered a good, safe place to live. People go here to
make money, not problems, residents say.

   ``I grew up here my whole life,'' said James Deleon, 23, a City
Council aide. ``It's New York that works. It's everything good
about the city without the bad. We worry about traffic problems and
garbage pickup, not two murderers on the loose.'' At Wendy's, city
workers pumped out sewer lines, searching for a weapon, clothing,
anything at all that might be a clue. Police dogs and their
handlers methodically searched for some faint scent of the gunmen.
A police van circled the neighborhood, its speakers blasting pleas
for witnesses to come forward.

   A police helicopter hovered and, for reasons authorities would
not disclose, officers searched for a green 1994 Toyota Maxima.

   Investigators said they believed that one of the gunmen had
either worked at the restaurant or knew someone who did. ``They
knew too much about Wendy's and how things worked there,'' one
official said.

   Law enforcement officials said they were pursuing several
possible suspects, including one 36-year-old man, a former
employee, who was arrested last summer in connection with a robbery
at a McDonald's in Queens. Other former Wendy's employees were also
potential suspects, investigators said.

   Ed Choe, a vice president for Wendy's, said the Flushing store
had been open for about two years and had never been robbed before
Wednesday.

   Several factors hampered investigators Thursday. A security
camera surveyed the front counter area of the store, but its
videotape was missing.

   The sound of gunfire may have been muffled by work crews who
were jack-hammering a sidewalk just four doors away. ``I heard
nothing because of the construction,'' said Muhammed Khalid,
manager of the Flushing News Outlet, also four doors away. ``Only
after the cops came did we learn of the shootings.''

   Even so, law enforcement officials said they had more than
enough leads to pursue, and they expressed confidence that they
would soon make arrests.

   ``It may be today, it may be tomorrow, it may be later,'' one
senior law enforcement official said Thursday, ``but we will get
these guys. If we can't catch guys like this, then shame on us.''
